t: Proverbs 19
On Life and Conduct
Better*pn is a poor man who walks in his integrity Than*ln he who is perverse in speech and is a fool.
Also*ln it is not good for a person to be without knowledge, And*ln he who hurries his footsteps errs.
The*ln foolishness of man ruins his way, And*ln his heart rages against the Lord.*s
Wealth*ln adds many friends, But*ln a poor man is separated from his friend.
A*ln false witness will not go unpunished, And*ln he who tells lies will not escape.
Many*ln will seek the favor of a generous man, And*ln every man is a friend to him who gives gifts.
All*ln the brothers of a poor man hate him; How*ln much more do his friends abandon him! He*ln pursues them*i with*i words, but*i they are gone.
He*ln who gets wisdom loves his own soul; He*ln who keeps understanding will find good.
A*ln false witness will not go unpunished, And*ln he who tells lies will perish.
Luxury*ln is not fitting for a fool; Much*ln less for a slave to rule over princes.
A*ln man’s discretion makes him slow to anger, And*ln it is his glory to overlook a transgression.
The*ln king’s wrath is like the roaring of a lion, But*ln his favor is like dew on the grass.
A*ln foolish son is destruction to his father, And*ln the contentions of a wife are a constant dripping.
House*ln and wealth are an inheritance from fathers, But*ln a prudent wife is from the Lord.*s
Laziness*ln casts into a deep sleep, And*ln an idle man will suffer hunger.
He*ln who keeps the commandment keeps his soul, But*iln he who is careless of conduct will die.
One*ln who is gracious to a poor man lends to the Lord,*s And*ln He will repay him for his good deed.
Discipline*ln your son while there is hope, And*ln do not desire his death.
A*iln man*i of*i great anger will bear the penalty, For*ln if you rescue him,*i you will only have to do it again.
Listen*ln to counsel and accept discipline, That*ln you may be wise the rest of your days.
Many*ln plans are in a man’s heart, But*ln the counsel of the Lord*s will stand.
What*ln is desirable in a man is his kindness, And*ln it*i is*i better to be a poor man than a liar.
The*ln fear of the Lord*s leads*i to life, So*ln that one may sleep satisfied, untouched by evil.
The*ln sluggard buries his hand in the dish, But*iln will not even bring it back to his mouth.
Strike*ln a scoffer and the naive may become shrewd, But*ln reprove one who has understanding and he will gain knowledge.
He*ln who assaults his*i father and*i drives his*i mother away Is*ln a shameful and disgraceful son.
Cease*ln listening, my son, to discipline, And*iln you*i will*i stray from the words of knowledge.
A*ln rascally witness makes a mockery of justice, And*ln the mouth of the wicked spreads iniquity.
Judgments*ln are prepared for scoffers, And*ln blows for the back of fools.
